\n The\n \n American Civil War\n \n (also\n \n known by other names\n \n ) was a\n \n civil war\n \n fought in the\n \n United States\n \n from 1861 to 1865, between the\n \n North\n \n and the\n \n South\n \n .\n \n \n [c]\n \n \n The most studied and\n \n written about\n \n episode in\n \n U.S. history\n \n ,\n \n \n [16]\n \n \n the Civil War began primarily as a result of the long-standing\n \n controversy\n \n over\n \n the enslavement of black people\n \n . War broke out in April 1861 when\n \n secessionist\n \n forces attacked\n \n Fort Sumter\n \n in\n \n South Carolina\n \n shortly after\n \n Abraham Lincoln\n \n had been\n \n inaugurated\n \n as the\n \n President of the United States\n \n . The loyalists of the\n \n Union\n \n in the North proclaimed support for the\n \n Constitution\n \n . They faced secessionists of the\n \n Confederate States\n \n in the South, who advocated for\n \n states\' rights\n \n to uphold slavery.\n

\n

\n Among the 34\n \n U.S. states\n \n in February 1861, secessionist partisans in seven Southern\n \n slave states\n \n declared state\n \n secessions\n \n from the country and unveiled their defiant formation of a\n \n Confederate States of America\n \n in rebellion against the U.S. Constitutional government. The Confederacy grew to control over half the territory in eleven states, and it claimed the additional states of Kentucky and Missouri by assertions from exiled native secessionists without territory or population. These were then given full representation in the Confederate Congress throughout the Civil War. The two remaining slave holding states of Delaware and Maryland were invited to join the Confederacy, but nothing substantial developed.\n

\n

\n The Confederate States was never diplomatically recognized by the\n \n government of the United States\n \n or by that of any foreign country.\n \n \n [d]\n \n \n The states that remained loyal to the U.S. were known as the Union.\n \n \n [e]\n \n \n The Union and the Confederacy quickly raised volunteer and conscription armies that fought mostly in the South over the course of four years. Intense combat left 620,000 to 750,000 people dead, more than the number of U.S. military deaths in all other wars combined.\n \n \n [f]\n \n \n

\n

\n The war effectively ended when General\n \n Robert E. Lee\n \n \n surrendered\n \n to General\n \n Ulysses S. Grant\n \n at the\n \n Battle of Appomattox Court House\n \n . Confederate generals throughout the southern states followed suit. Much of the South\'s infrastructure was destroyed, especially the transportation systems. The Confederacy\n \n collapsed\n \n , slavery\n \n was abolished\n \n , and four million black slaves were freed. During the\n \n Reconstruction Era\n \n that followed the war, national unity was slowly restored, the national government expanded its power, and\n \n civil rights\n \n were granted to freed black slaves through\n \n amendments to the Constitution\n \n and federal legislation.\n

\n \n Overview\n \n

\n
\n
\n \n \n \n
\n
\n \n \n
\n Union flag\n
\n
\n
\n

\n In the\n \n 1860 presidential election\n \n ,\n \n Republicans\n \n , led by\n \n Abraham Lincoln\n \n , supported banning slavery in all the\n \n U.S. territories\n \n . The Southern states viewed this as a violation of their constitutional rights and as the first step in a grander Republican plan to eventually abolish slavery. The three pro-Union candidates together received an overwhelming 82% majority of the votes cast nationally: Republican Lincoln\'s votes centered in the north,\n \n Democrat\n \n \n Stephen A. Douglas\n \n \' votes were distributed nationally and\n \n Constitutional Unionist\n \n \n John Bell\n \n \'s votes centered in\n \n Tennessee\n \n ,\n \n Kentucky\n \n , and\n \n Virginia\n \n . The Republican Party, dominant in the North, secured a\n \n plurality\n \n of the popular votes and a majority of the electoral votes nationally; thus Lincoln was constitutionally elected president. He was the first Republican Party candidate to win the presidency. However, before\n \n his inauguration\n \n , seven slave states with\n \n cotton\n \n -based economies declared secession and formed the\n \n Confederacy\n \n . The first six to declare secession had the highest proportions of slaves in their populations, with an average of 49 percent.\n \n \n [18]\n \n \n Of those states whose legislatures resolved for secession, the first seven voted with split majorities for unionist candidates Douglas and Bell (\n \n Georgia\n \n with 51% and\n \n Louisiana\n \n with 55%), or with sizable minorities for those unionists (\n \n Alabama\n \n with 46%,\n \n Mississippi\n \n with 40%,\n \n Florida\n \n with 38%,\n \n Texas\n \n with 25%, and\n \n South Carolina\n \n , which cast\n \n Electoral College\n \n votes without a popular vote for president).\n \n \n [19]\n \n \n Of these, only Texas held a referendum on secession.\n

\n
\n
\n \n \n \n
\n
\n \n \n
\n Confederate Army flag\n
\n
\n
\n

\n Eight remaining slave states continued to reject calls for secession. Outgoing Democratic President\n \n James Buchanan\n \n and the incoming Republicans rejected secession as illegal.\n \n Lincoln\'s March 4, 1861, inaugural address\n \n declared that his administration would not initiate a\n \n civil war\n \n . Speaking directly to the "Southern States", he attempted to calm their fears of any threats to slavery, reaffirming, "I have no purpose, directly or indirectly to interfere with the institution of slavery in the United States where it exists. I believe I have no lawful right to do so, and I have no inclination to do so."\n \n \n [20]\n \n \n After Confederate forces seized numerous federal forts within territory claimed by the Confederacy, efforts at compromise failed and both sides prepared for war. The Confederates assumed that\n \n European\n \n countries were so dependent on "\n \n King Cotton\n \n " that they would intervene,\n \n \n [21]\n \n \n but none did, and none recognized the new Confederate States of America.\n

\n

\n Hostilities began on April 12, 1861, when Confederate forces\n \n fired upon Fort Sumter\n \n . While in the\n \n Western Theater\n \n the Union made significant permanent gains, in the\n \n Eastern Theater\n \n , the battle was inconclusive during 18611862. Later, in September 1862, Lincoln issued the\n \n Emancipation Proclamation\n \n , which made ending slavery a war goal.\n \n \n [22]\n \n \n To the west, by summer 1862 the Union destroyed the Confederate river navy, then much of its western armies, and seized\n \n New Orleans\n \n . The successful 1863 Union\n \n siege of Vicksburg\n \n split the Confederacy in two at the\n \n Mississippi River\n \n . In 1863,\n \n Robert E. Lee\n \n \'s Confederate incursion north ended at the\n \n Battle of Gettysburg\n \n . Western successes led to\n \n Ulysses S. Grant\n \n \'s command of all Union armies in 1864. Inflicting an ever-tightening\n \n naval blockade\n \n of Confederate ports, the Union marshaled the resources and manpower to attack the Confederacy from all directions, leading to the\n \n fall of Atlanta\n \n to\n \n William T. Sherman\n \n and\n \n his march to the sea\n \n . The last significant battles raged around the\n \n Siege of Petersburg\n \n . Lee\'s escape attempt ended with his\n \n surrender at Appomattox Court House\n \n , on April 9, 1865. While the military war was coming to an end, the political reintegration of the nation was to take another 12 years, known as the\n \n Reconstruction Era\n \n .\n

\n
\n
\n \n \n \n
\n
\n \n \n
\n Confederate flag, the "Stars and Bars".\n
\n
\n
\n

\n The American Civil War was among the earliest\n \n industrial wars\n \n . Railroads, the\n \n telegraph\n \n , steamships and\n \n iron-clad\n \n ships, and mass-produced weapons were employed extensively. The mobilization of civilian factories, mines, shipyards, banks, transportation, and food supplies all foreshadowed the impact of industrialization in\n \n World War I\n \n ,\n \n World War II\n \n , and subsequent conflicts. It remains the deadliest war in\n \n American history\n \n . From 1861 to 1865, it is estimated that 620,000 to 750,000 soldiers died,\n \n \n [23]\n \n \n along with an undetermined number of\n \n civilians\n \n .\n \n \n [g]\n \n \n By one estimate, the war claimed the lives of 10 percent of all Northern men 2045 years old, and 30 percent of all Southern white men aged 1840.\n \n \n [25]\n \n \n

\n

\n \n Causes of secession\n \n

\n
\n Main articles:\n \n Origins of the American Civil War\n \n and\n \n Timeline of events leading to the American Civil War\n \n
\n

\n The causes of secession were complex and have been controversial since the war began, but most academic scholarsidentifyslavery as a central cause of the war. James C. Bradford wrote that the issue has been further complicated by\n \n historical revisionists\n \n , who have tried to offer a variety of reasons for the war.\n \n \n [26]\n \n \n Slavery was the central source of escalating political tension in the\n \n 1850s\n \n . The\n \n Republican Party\n \n was determined to prevent any spread of slavery, and many Southern leaders had threatened secession if the Republican candidate,\n \n Lincoln\n \n , won the\n \n 1860 election\n \n . After Lincoln won, many Southern leaders felt that disunion was their only option, fearing that the loss of representation would hamper their ability to promote pro-slavery acts and policies.\n \n \n [27]\n \n \n \n \n [28]\n \n \n

\n

\n \n Slavery\n \n

\n
\n
\n \n \n \n
\n
\n \n \n
\n
\n \n Status of the states, 1861\n \n
\n
\n \n \n States that seceded before April 15, 1861\n
\n
\n \n \n States that seceded after April 15, 1861\n
\n
\n \n \n Union states that permitted slavery\n
\n
\n \n \n Union states that banned slavery\n
\n
\n \n \n Territories\n
\n
\n
\n
\n

\n Slavery was a major cause of disunion.\n \n \n [29]\n \n \n Although there were opposing views even in the Union States,\n \n \n [30]\n \n \n \n \n [31]\n \n \n most northern soldiers were mostly indifferent on the subject of slavery,\n \n \n [32]\n \n \n while Confederates fought the war mainly to protect a southern society of which slavery was an integral part.\n \n \n [33]\n \n \n From the anti-slavery perspective, the issue was primarily about whether the system of slavery was an anachronistic evil that was incompatible with\n \n republicanism\n \n . The strategy of the anti-slavery forces was containmentto stop the expansion and thus put slavery on a path to gradual extinction.\n \n \n [34]\n \n \n The slave-holding interests in the South denounced this strategy as infringing upon their Constitutional rights.\n \n \n [35]\n \n \n Southern whites believed that the emancipation of slaves would destroy the South\'s economy, due to the large amount of capital invested in slaves and fears of integrating the ex-slave black population.\n \n \n [36]\n \n \n In particular, Southerners feared a repeat of\n \n "the horrors of Santo Domingo"\n \n , in which nearly all white people including men, women, children, and even many sympathetic to abolition were killed after the\n \n successful slave revolt in Haiti\n \n . Historian Thomas Fleming points to the historical phrase "a disease in the public mind" used by critics of this idea, and proposes it contributed to the segregation in the\n \n Jim Crow\n \n era following emancipation.\n \n \n [37]\n \n \n These fears were exacerbated by the\n \n recent attempt\n \n of\n \n John Brown\n \n to instigate an armed slave rebellion in the South.\n

\n

\n Slavery was illegal in much of the North, having been outlawed in the late 18th and early 19th centuries. It was also fading in the border states and in Southern cities, but it was expanding in the highly profitable cotton districts of the rural South and Southwest. Subsequent writers on the American Civil War looked to several factors explaining the geographic divide.\n \n [\n \n \n \n citation needed\n \n \n \n ]\n \n

\n

\n \n Territorial crisis\n \n

\n
\n Further information:\n \n Slave and free states\n \n
\n

\n Between 1803 and 1854, the United States achieved a vast expansion of territory through purchase, negotiation, and conquest. At first, the new states carved out of these territories entering the union were apportioned equally between slave and free states. Pro- and anti-slavery forces collided over the territories west of the Mississippi.\n \n \n [38]\n \n \n

\n

\n With the conquest of northern\n \n Mexico\n \n west to\n \n California\n \n in 1848, slaveholding interests looked forward to expanding into these lands and perhaps Cuba and Central America as well.\n \n \n [39]\n \n \n \n \n [40]\n \n \n Northern "free soil" interests vigorously sought to curtail any further expansion of slave territory. The\n \n Compromise of 1850\n \n over California balanced a free-soil state with stronger fugitive slave laws for a political settlement after four years of strife in the 1840s. But the states admitted following California were all free: Minnesota (1858), Oregon (1859) and Kansas (1861). In the Southern states the question of the territorial expansion of slavery westward again became explosive.\n \n \n [41]\n \n \n Both the South and the North drew the same conclusion: "The power to decide the question of slavery for the territories was the power to determine the future of slavery itself."\n \n \n [42]\n \n \n \n \n [43]\n \n \n

\n \n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n \n \n \n
\n
\n Sen. Stephen Douglas, author of the\n \n KansasNebraska Act\n \n of 1854\n
\n
\n
\n
\n \n \n \n
\n
\n Sen. John J. Crittenden, of the 1860\n \n Crittenden Compromise\n \n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n

\n By 1860, four doctrines had emerged to answer the question of federal control in the territories, and they all claimed they were sanctioned by the Constitution, implicitly or explicitly.\n \n \n [44]\n \n \n The first of these "conservative" theories, represented by the\n \n Constitutional Union Party\n \n , argued that the\n \n Missouri Compromise\n \n apportionment of territory north for free soil and south for slavery should become a Constitutional mandate. The\n \n Crittenden Compromise\n \n of 1860 was an expression of this view.\n \n \n [45]\n \n \n

\n

\n The second doctrine of Congressional preeminence, championed by Abraham Lincoln and the Republican Party, insisted that the Constitution did not bind legislators to a policy of balancethat slavery could be excluded in a territory as it was done in the\n \n Northwest Ordinance\n \n of 1787 at the discretion of Congress;\n \n \n [46]\n \n \n thus Congress could restrict human bondage, but never establish it. The\n \n Wilmot Proviso\n \n announced this position in 1846.\n \n \n [47]\n \n \n

\n

\n Senator\n \n Stephen A. Douglas\n \n proclaimed the doctrine of territorial or "popular" sovereigntywhich asserted that the settlers in a territory had the same rights as states in the Union to establish or disestablish slavery as a purely local matter.\n \n \n [48]\n \n \n The\n \n KansasNebraska Act\n \n of 1854 legislated this doctrine.\n \n \n [49]\n \n \n In the Kansas Territory, years of\n \n pro and anti-slavery violence\n \n and political conflict erupted; the congressional House of Representatives voted to admit Kansas as a free state in early 1860, but its admission in the Senate was delayed until January 1861, after the 1860 elections when Southern states began to leave.\n \n \n [50]\n \n \n

\n

\n The fourth theory was advocated by Mississippi Senator\n \n Jefferson Davis\n \n ,\n \n \n [51]\n \n \n one of state sovereignty ("states\' rights"),\n \n \n [52]\n \n \n also known as the "Calhoun doctrine",\n \n \n [53]\n \n \n named after the South Carolinian political theorist and statesman\n \n John C. Calhoun\n \n .\n \n \n [54]\n \n \n Rejecting the arguments for federal authority or self-government, state sovereignty would empower states to promote the expansion of slavery as part of the federal union under the U.S. Constitution.\n \n \n [55]\n \n \n "States\' rights" was an ideology formulated and applied as a means of advancing slave state interests through federal authority.\n \n \n [56]\n \n \n As historian Thomas L. Krannawitter points out, the "Southern demand for federal slave protection represented a demand for an unprecedented expansion of federal power."\n \n \n [57]\n \n \n \n \n [58]\n \n \n These four doctrines comprised the dominant ideologies presented to the American public on the matters of slavery, the territories, and the U.S. Constitution before the 1860 presidential election.\n \n \n [59]\n \n \n

\n

\n \n \n \n States\' rights\n \n

\n

\n The South argued that just as each state had decided to join the Union, a state had the right to secedeleave the Unionat any time. Northerners (including President Buchanan) rejected that notion as opposed to the will of the\n \n Founding Fathers\n \n , who said they were setting up a perpetual union.\n \n \n [60]\n \n \n Historian James McPherson writes concerning states\' rights and other non-slavery explanations:\n

\n \n
\n

\n While\n \n one or more of these interpretations\n \n remain popular among the\n \n Sons of Confederate Veterans\n \n and other Southern heritage groups, few professional historians now subscribe to them. Of all these interpretations, the states\'-rights argument is perhaps the weakest. It fails to ask the question, states\' rights for what purpose? States\' rights, or sovereignty, was always more a means than an end, an instrument to achieve a certain goal more than a principle.\n \n \n [61]\n \n \n

\n
\n

\n \n Sectionalism\n \n

\n

\n \n Sectionalism\n \n resulted from the different economies, social structure, customs, and political values of the North and South.\n \n \n [62]\n \n \n \n \n [63]\n \n \n Regional tensions came to a head during the\n \n War of 1812\n \n , resulting in the\n \n Hartford Convention\n \n , which manifested Northern dissastisfaction with a foreign trade embargo that affected the industrial North disproportionately, the\n \n Three-Fifths Compromise\n \n , dilution of Northern power by new states, and a succession of\n \n Southern presidents\n \n . Sectionalism increased steadily between 1800 and 1860 as the North, which phased slavery out of existence, industrialized, urbanized, and built prosperous farms, while the deep South concentrated on plantation agriculture based on slave labor, together with\n \n subsistence farming\n \n for poor whites. In the 1840s and 50s, the issue of accepting slavery (in the guise of rejecting slave-owning bishops and missionaries) split the nation\'s largest religious denominations (the Methodist, Baptist, and Presbyterian churches) into separate Northern and Southern denominations.\n \n \n [64]\n \n \n

\n

\n Historians have debated whether economic differences between the mainly industrial North and the mainly agricultural South helped cause the war. Most historians now disagree with the\n \n economic determinism\n \n of historian\n \n Charles A. Beard\n \n in the 1920s, and emphasize that Northern and Southern economies were largely complementary. While socially different, the sections economically benefited each other.\n \n \n [65]\n \n \n \n \n [66]\n \n \n

\n

\n \n Protectionism\n \n

\n

\n Slave owners preferred low-cost manual labor with no mechanization. Northern manufacturing interests supported tariffs and protectionism while southern planters demanded free trade.\n \n \n [67]\n \n \n The Democrats in Congress, controlled by Southerners, wrote the tariff laws in the 1830s, 1840s, and 1850s, and kept reducing rates so that the 1857 rates were the lowest since 1816. The Republicans called for an increase in tariffs in the 1860 election. The increases were only enacted in 1861 after Southerners resigned their seats in Congress.\n \n \n [68]\n \n \n \n \n [69]\n \n \n The tariff issue was a Northern grievance. However,\n \n neo-Confederate\n \n writers have claimed it as a Southern grievance. In 186061 none of the groups that proposed compromises to head off secession raised the tariff issue.\n \n \n [70]\n \n \n Pamphleteers North and South rarely mentioned the tariff.\n \n \n [71]\n \n \n

\n

\n \n Nationalism and honor\n \n

\n

\n Nationalism was a powerful force in the early 19th century, with famous spokesmen such as\n \n Andrew Jackson\n \n and\n \n Daniel Webster\n \n . While practically all Northerners supported the Union, Southerners were split between those loyal to the entire United States (called "unionists") and those loyal primarily to the southern region and then the Confederacy.\n \n \n [72]\n \n \n \n C. Vann Woodward\n \n said of the latter group,\n

\n \n
\n

\n A great slave society... had grown up and miraculously flourished in the heart of a thoroughly bourgeois and partly puritanical republic. It had renounced its bourgeois origins and elaborated and painfully rationalized its institutional, legal, metaphysical, and religious defenses... When the crisis came it chose to fight. It proved to be the death struggle of a society, which went down in ruins.\n \n \n [73]\n \n \n

\n
\n

\n Perceived insults to Southern collective honor included the enormous popularity of\n \n \n Uncle Tom\'s Cabin\n \n \n (1852)\n \n \n [74]\n \n \n and the actions of abolitionist\n \n John Brown\n \n in trying to incite a\n \n slave rebellion\n \n in 1859.\n \n \n [75]\n \n \n

\n

\n While the South moved towards a Southern nationalism, leaders in the North were also becoming more nationally minded, and they rejected any notion of splitting the Union. The Republican national electoral platform of 1860 warned that Republicans regarded disunion as\n \n treason\n \n and would not tolerate it: "We denounce those threats of disunion... as denying the vital principles of a free government, and as an avowal of contemplated treason, which it is the imperative duty of an indignant people sternly to rebuke and forever silence."\n \n \n [76]\n \n \n The South ignored the warnings: Southerners did not realize how ardently the North would fight to hold the Union together.\n \n \n [77]\n \n \n

\n

\n \n \n \n Lincoln\'s election\n \n

\n
\n Main article:\n \n United States presidential election, 1860\n \n
\n
\n
\n \n \n \n
\n
\n \n \n
\n Abraham Lincoln in 1864\n
\n
\n
\n

\n The election of Abraham Lincoln in November 1860 was the final trigger for secession.\n \n \n [78]\n \n \n Efforts at compromise, including the "\n \n Corwin Amendment\n \n " and the "\n \n Crittenden Compromise\n \n ", failed.\nSouthern leaders feared that Lincoln would stop the expansion of slavery and put it on a course toward extinction. The slave states, which had already become a minority in the House of Representatives, were now facing a future as a perpetual minority in the Senate and Electoral College against an increasingly powerful North. Before Lincoln took office in March 1861, seven slave states had declared their secession and joined to form the Confederacy.\n

\n

\n According to Lincoln, the people had shown that they can be successful in\n \n establishing\n \n and\n \n administering\n \n a republic, but a third challenge faced the nation,\n \n maintaining\n \n a republic based on the people\'s vote against an attempt to overthrow it.\n \n \n [79]\n \n \n

\n

\n \n Outbreak of the war\n \n

\n

\n \n Secession crisis\n \n

\n

\n The election of Lincoln provoked the legislature of South Carolina to call a state convention to consider secession. Prior to the war, South Carolina did more than any other Southern state to advance the notion that a state had the right to\n \n nullify\n \n federal laws, and even to secede from the United States. The convention summoned unanimously voted to secede on December 20, 1860, and adopted the "\n \n Declaration of the Immediate Causes Which Induce and Justify the Secession of South Carolina from the Federal Union\n \n ". It argued for states\' rights for slave owners in the South, but contained a complaint about states\' rights in the North in the form of opposition to the\n \n Fugitive Slave Act\n \n , claiming that Northern states were not fulfilling their federal obligations under the Constitution. The "cotton states" of Mississippi, Florida, Alabama, Georgia, Louisiana, and Texas followed suit, seceding in January and February 1861.\n

\n
\n
\n \n \n \n
\n
\n \n \n
\n The first published imprint of secession, a\n \n broadside\n \n issued by the\n \n \n Charleston Mercury\n \n \n , December 20, 1860\n
\n
\n
\n

\n Among the ordinances of secession passed by the individual states, those of threeTexas, Alabama, and Virginiaspecifically mentioned the plight of the "slaveholding states" at the hands of northern abolitionists. The rest make no mention of the slavery issue, and are often brief announcements of the dissolution of ties by the legislatures.\n \n \n [80]\n \n \n However, at least four statesSouth Carolina,\n \n \n [81]\n \n \n Mississippi,\n \n \n [82]\n \n \n Georgia,\n \n \n [83]\n \n \n and Texas\n \n \n [84]\n \n \n also passed lengthy and detailed explanations of their causes for secession, all of which laid the blame squarely on the movement to abolish slavery and that movement\'s influence over the politics of the northern states. The southern states believed slaveholding was a constitutional right because of the\n \n Fugitive slave clause\n \n of the Constitution.\n\nThese states agreed to form a new federal government, the\n \n Confederate States of America\n \n , on February 4, 1861.\n \n \n [85]\n \n \n They took control of federal forts and other properties within their boundaries with little resistance from outgoing President\n \n James Buchanan\n \n , whose term ended on March 4, 1861. Buchanan said that the\n \n Dred Scott decision\n \n was proof that the South had no reason for secession, and that the Union "was intended to be perpetual", but that "The power by force of arms to compel a State to remain in the Union" was not among the "enumerated powers granted to Congress".\n \n \n [86]\n \n \n One quarter of the U.S. Armythe entire garrison in Texaswas surrendered in February 1861 to state forces by its commanding general,\n \n David E. Twiggs\n \n , who then joined the Confederacy.\n

\n

\n As Southerners resigned their seats in the Senate and the House, Republicans were able to pass bills for projects that had been blocked by Southern Senators before the war. These included the\n \n Morrill Tariff\n \n , land grant colleges (the\n \n Morrill Act\n \n ), a\n \n Homestead Act\n \n , a transcontinental railroad (the\n \n Pacific Railway Acts\n \n ),\n \n \n [87]\n \n \n the\n \n National Banking Act\n \n and the authorization of\n \n United States Notes\n \n by the Legal Tender Act of 1862. The\n \n Revenue Act of 1861\n \n introduced the\n \n income tax\n \n to help finance the war.\n

\n

\n On December 18, 1860, the\n \n Crittenden Compromise\n \n was proposed to re-establish the\n \n Missouri Compromise\n \n line by constitutionally banning slavery in territories to the north of the line while guaranteeing it to the south. The adoption of this compromise likely would have prevented the secession of every southern state apart from South Carolina, but Lincoln and the Republicans rejected it.\n \n \n [88]\n \n \n It was then proposed to hold a national referendum on the compromise. The Republicans again rejected the idea, although a majority of both Northerners and Southerners would have voted in favor of it.\n \n \n [89]\n \n \n A pre-war February\n \n Peace Conference of 1861\n \n met in Washington, proposing a solution similar to that of the Crittenden compromise, it was rejected by Congress. The Republicans proposed an\n \n alternative compromise\n \n to not interfere with slavery where it existed but the South regarded it as insufficient. Nonetheless, the remaining eight slave states rejected pleas to join the Confederacy following a two-to-one no-vote in Virginia\'s First Secessionist Convention on April 4, 1861.\n \n \n [90]\n \n \n

\n
\n
\n \n \n \n
\n
\n \n \n
\n \n Jefferson Davis\n \n ,\n \n President of the Confederate States of America\n \n (18611865)\n
\n
\n
\n

\n On March 4, 1861,\n \n Abraham Lincoln\n \n was sworn in as President. In his\n \n inaugural address\n \n , he argued that the Constitution was a\n \n \n more perfect union\n \n \n than the earlier\n \n Articles of Confederation and Perpetual Union\n \n , that it was a binding contract, and called any secession "legally void".\n \n \n [91]\n \n \n He had no intent to invade Southern states, nor did he intend to end slavery where it existed, but said that he would use force to maintain possession of Federal property. The government would make no move to recover post offices, and if resisted, mail delivery would end at state lines. Where popular conditions did not allow peaceful enforcement of Federal law, U.S. marshals and judges would be withdrawn. No mention was made of bullion lost from U.S. mints in Louisiana, Georgia, and North Carolina. He stated that it would be U.S. policy to only collect import duties at its ports; there could be no serious injury to the South to justify armed revolution during his administration. His speech closed with a plea for restoration of the bonds of union, famously calling on "the mystic chords of memory" binding the two regions.\n \n \n [91]\n \n \n

\n

\n The South sent delegations to Washington and offered to pay for the federal properties\n \n [\n \n \n \n which?\n \n \n \n ]\n \n and enter into a peace treaty with the United States. Lincoln rejected any negotiations with Confederate agents because he claimed the Confederacy was not a legitimate government, and that making any treaty with it would be tantamount to recognition of it as a sovereign government.\n \n \n [92]\n \n \n Secretary of State\n \n William Seward\n \n , who at the time saw himself as the real governor or "prime minister" behind the throne of the inexperienced Lincoln, engaged in unauthorized and indirect negotiations that failed.\n \n \n [92]\n \n \n President Lincoln was determined to hold all remaining Union-occupied forts in the Confederacy:\n \n Fort Monroe\n \n in Virginia,\n \n Fort Pickens\n \n ,\n \n Fort Jefferson\n \n and\n \n Fort Taylor\n \n in Florida, and\n \n Fort Sumter\n \n located at the cockpit of secession in Charleston, South Carolina.\n

\n

\n \n Battle of Fort Sumter\n \n

\n
\n Main article:\n \n Battle of Fort Sumter\n \n
\n
\n
\n \n \n \n
\n
\n \n \n
\n The Confederate "Stars and Bars" flying from Fort Sumter\n
\n
\n
\n

\n Fort Sumter was located in the middle of the harbor of\n \n Charleston\n \n , South Carolina. Its garrison recently moved there to avoid incidents with local militias in the streets of the city. Lincoln told Maj. Anderson to hold on until fired upon. Jefferson Davis ordered the surrender of the fort. Anderson gave a conditional reply that the Confederate government rejected, and Davis ordered General\n \n P. G. T. Beauregard\n \n to attack the fort before a relief expedition could arrive. He bombarded Fort Sumter on April 1213, forcing its capitulation.\n

\n

\n The attack on Fort Sumter rallied the North to the defense of American nationalism. Historian\n \n Allan Nevins\n \n said:\n

\n
\n
\n The thunderclap of Sumter produced a startling crystallization of Northern sentiment.... Anger swept the land. From every side came news of mass meetings, speeches, resolutions, tenders of business support, the muster of companies and regiments, the determined action of governors and legislatures."\n \n \n [93]\n \n \n
\n
\n
\n
\n \n \n \n
\n
\n \n \n
\n Mass meeting in New York City April 20, 1861, to support the Union.\n
\n
\n
\n

\n Union leaders incorrectly assumed that only a minority of Southerners were in favor of secession and that there were large numbers of southern Unionists that could be counted on. Had Northerners realized that most Southerners favored secession, they might have hesitated at attempting the enormous task of conquering a united South.\n \n \n [94]\n \n \n

\n

\n Lincoln called on all the states to send forces to recapture the fort and other federal properties. The scale of the rebellion appeared to be small, so he called for only\n \n 75,000 volunteers\n \n for 90days.\n \n \n [95]\n \n \n The governor of Massachusetts had state regiments on trains headed south the next day. In western Missouri, local secessionists seized\n \n Liberty Arsenal\n \n .\n \n \n [96]\n \n \n On May 3, 1861, Lincoln called for an additional 42,000 volunteers for a period of three years.\n \n \n [97]\n \n \n

\n

\n Four states in the middle and upper South had repeatedly rejected Confederate overtures, but now\n \n Virginia\n \n ,\n \n Tennessee\n \n ,\n \n Arkansas\n \n , and\n \n North Carolina\n \n refused to send forces against their neighbors, declared their secession, and joined the Confederacy. To reward Virginia, the Confederate capital was moved to\n \n Richmond\n \n .\n \n \n [98]\n \n \n

\n

\n \n Attitude of the border states\n \n

\n
\n Main article:\n \n Border states (American Civil War)\n \n
\n
\n
\n \n \n \n
\n
\n \n \n
\n US Secession map 1863. The\n \n Union\n \n vs. the\n \n Confederacy.\n \n
\n \n \n Union states\n
\n
\n \n \n Union territories not permitting slavery\n
\n
\n \n \n \n Border Union states, permitting slavery\n \n
\n (One of these states,\n \n West Virginia\n \n was created in 1863)\n
\n \n \n Confederate states\n
\n
\n \n \n Union territories that permitted slavery (claimed by Confederacy) at the start of the war, but where slavery was outlawed by the U.S. in 1862\n
\n
\n
\n
\n

\n \n Maryland\n \n ,\n \n Delaware\n \n ,\n \n Missouri\n \n , and\n \n Kentucky\n \n were slave states that were opposed to both secession and coercing the South.\n \n West Virginia\n \n then joined them as an additional border state after it separated from\n \n Virginia\n \n and became a state of the\n \n Union\n \n in 1863.\n

\n

\n Maryland\'s territory surrounded the United States\' capital of\n \n Washington, DC\n \n and could cut it off from the North.\n \n \n [99]\n \n \n It had numerous anti-Lincoln officials who tolerated anti-army\n \n rioting in Baltimore\n \n and the burning of bridges, both aimed at hindering the passage of troops to the South. Maryland\'s legislature voted overwhelmingly (5313) to stay in the Union, but also rejected hostilities with its southern neighbors, voting to close Maryland\'s rail lines to prevent them from being used for war.\n \n \n [100]\n \n \n Lincoln responded by establishing\n \n martial law\n \n and unilaterally suspending\n \n habeas corpus\n \n in Maryland, along with sending in militia units from the North.\n \n \n [101]\n \n \n Lincoln rapidly took control of Maryland and the District of Columbia by seizing many prominent figures, including arresting 1/3 of the members of the\n \n Maryland General Assembly\n \n on the day it reconvened.\n \n \n [100]\n \n \n \n \n [102]\n \n \n All were held without trial, ignoring a ruling by the Chief Justice of the U.S. Supreme Court\n \n Roger Taney\n \n , a Maryland native, that only Congress (and not the president) could suspend habeas corpus (\n \n Ex parte Merryman\n \n ). Indeed, federal troops imprisoned a prominent Baltimore newspaper editor,\n \n Frank Key Howard\n \n , Francis Scott Key\'s grandson, after he criticized Lincoln in an editorial for ignoring the Supreme Court Chief Justice\'s ruling.\n \n \n [103]\n \n \n

\n

\n In Missouri, an\n \n elected convention\n \n on secession voted decisively to remain within the Union. When pro-Confederate Governor\n \n Claiborne F. Jackson\n \n called out the state militia, it was attacked by federal forces under General\n \n Nathaniel Lyon\n \n , who chased the governor and the rest of the State Guard to the southwestern corner of the state (\n \n see also\n \n :\n \n Missouri secession\n \n ). In the resulting vacuum, the convention on secession reconvened and took power as the Unionist provisional government of Missouri.\n \n \n [104]\n \n \n

\n

\n Kentucky did not secede; for a time, it declared itself neutral. When Confederate forces entered the state in September 1861, neutrality ended and the state reaffirmed its Union status, while trying to maintain slavery. During a brief invasion by Confederate forces, Confederate sympathizers organized a secession convention, inaugurated a governor, and gained recognition from the Confederacy. The rebel government soon went into exile and never controlled Kentucky.\n \n \n [105]\n \n \n

\n

\n After Virginia\'s secession, a\n \n Unionist government\n \n in\n \n Wheeling\n \n asked 48 counties to vote on an ordinance to create a new state on October 24, 1861. A voter turnout of 34 percent approved the statehood bill (96 percent approving).\n \n \n [106]\n \n \n The inclusion of 24 secessionist counties\n \n \n [107]\n \n \n in the state and the ensuing guerrilla war engaged about 40,000 Federal troops for much of the war.\n \n \n [108]\n \n \n \n \n [109]\n \n \n Congress admitted\n \n West Virginia\n \n to the Union on June 20, 1863. West Virginia provided about 20,00022,000 soldiers to both the Confederacy and the Union.\n \n \n [110]\n \n \n

\n

\n A Unionist secession attempt occurred in\n \n East Tennessee\n \n , but was suppressed by the Confederacy, which arrested over 3,000 men suspected of being loyal to the Union. They were held without trial.\n \n \n [111]\n \n \n

\n

\n \n General features of the War\n \n

\n
\n See also:\n \n List of American Civil War battles\n \n and\n \n Military leadership in the American Civil War\n \n
\n

\n The Civil War was a contest marked by the ferocity and frequency of battle. Over four years, 237 named battles were fought, as were many more minor actions and skirmishes, which were often characterized by their bitter intensity and high casualties. In his book\n \n The American Civil War\n \n , John Keegan writes that "The American Civil War was to prove one of the most ferocious wars ever fought". Without geographic objectives, the only target for each side was the enemy\'s soldier.\n \n \n [112]\n \n \n

\n

\n \n Mobilization\n \n

\n
\n See also:\n \n Child soldiers in the American Civil War\n \n
\n

\n As the first seven states began organizing a Confederacy in Montgomery, the entire U.S. army numbered 16,000. However, Northern governors had begun to mobilize their militias.\n \n \n [113]\n \n \n The Confederate Congress authorized the new nation up to 100,000 troops sent by governors as early as February. By May, Jefferson Davis was pushing for 100,000 men under arms for one year or the duration, and that was answered in kind by the U.S. Congress.\n \n \n [114]\n \n \n \n \n [115]\n \n \n \n \n [116]\n \n \n

\n

\n In the first year of the war, both sides had far more volunteers than they could effectively train and equip. After the initial enthusiasm faded, reliance on the cohort of young men who came of age every year and wanted to join was not enough. Both sides used a draft law\n \n conscription\n \n as a device to encourage or force volunteering; relatively few were drafted and served. The Confederacy passed a draft law in April 1862 for young men aged 18 to 35; overseers of slaves, government officials, and clergymen were exempt.\n \n \n [117]\n \n \n The U.S. Congress followed in July, authorizing a militia draft within a state when it could not meet its quota with volunteers. European\n \n immigrants\n \n joined the\n \n Union Army\n \n in large numbers, including 177,000 born in Germany and 144,000 born in Ireland.\n \n \n [118]\n \n \n

\n

\n When the Emancipation Proclamation went into effect in January 1863, ex-slaves were energetically recruited by the states, and used to meet the state quotas. States and local communities offered higher and higher cash bonuses for white volunteers. Congress tightened the law in March 1863. Men selected in the draft could provide substitutes or, until mid-1864, pay commutation money. Many eligibles pooled their money to cover the cost of anyone drafted. Families used the substitute provision to select which man should go into the army and which should stay home. There was much evasion and overt resistance to the draft, especially in Catholic areas. The\n \n draft riot in New York City\n \n in July 1863 involved Irish immigrants who had been signed up as citizens to swell the vote of the\n \n city\'s Democratic political machine\n \n , not realizing it made them liable for the draft.\n \n \n [119]\n \n \n Of the 168,649 men procured for the Union through the draft, 117,986 were substitutes, leaving only 50,663 who had their personal services conscripted.\n \n \n [120]\n \n \n

\n
\n
\n \n \n \n
\n
\n \n \n
\n Rioters attacking a building during the\n \n New York anti-draft riots\n \n of 1863\n
\n
\n
\n

\n In both the North and South, the draft laws were highly unpopular. In the North, some 120,000 men evaded conscription, many of them fleeing to Canada, and another 280,000 soldiers deserted during the war.\n \n \n [121]\n \n \n At least 100,000 Southerners deserted, or about 10 percent. In the South, many men deserted temporarily to take care of their distressed families, then returned to their units.\n \n \n [122]\n \n \n In the North, "bounty jumpers" enlisted to get the generous bonus, deserted, then went back to a second recruiting station under a different name to sign up again for a second bonus; 141 were caught and executed.\n \n \n [123]\n \n \n

\n

\n From a tiny frontier force in 1860, the Union and Confederate armies had grown into the "largest and most efficient armies in the world" within a few years. European observers at the time dismissed them as amateur and unprofessional, but British historian\n \n John Keegan\n \n concluded that each outmatched the French, Prussian and Russian armies of the time, and but for the Atlantic, would have threatened any of them with defeat.\n \n \n [124]\n \n \n

\n

\n \n Motivation\n \n

\n

\n Perman and Taylor (2010) write that historians are of two minds on why millions of men seemed so eager to fight, suffer and die over four years:\n

\n \n
\n

\n Some historians emphasize that Civil War soldiers were driven by political ideology, holding firm beliefs about the importance of liberty, Union, or state rights, or about the need to protect or to destroy slavery. Others point to less overtly political reasons to fight, such as the defense of one\'s home and family, or the honor and brotherhood to be preserved when fighting alongside other men. Most historians agree that no matter what a soldier thought about when he went into the war, the experience of combat affected him profoundly and sometimes altered his reasons for continuing the fight.\n \n \n [125]\n \n \n

\n
\n

\n \n Prisoners\n \n

\n
\n Main article:\n \n American Civil War prison camps\n \n
\n

\n At the start of the civil war, a system of paroles operated. Captives agreed not to fight until they were officially exchanged. Meanwhile, they were held in camps run by their army. They were paid, but they were not allowed to perform any military duties.\n \n \n [126]\n \n \n The system of exchanges collapsed in 1863 when the Confederacy refused to exchange black prisoners. After that, about 56,000 of the 409,000 POWs died in prisons during the war, accounting for nearly 10 percent of the conflict\'s fatalities.\n \n \n [127]\n \n \n

\n

\n \n Naval tactics\n \n

\n

\n The small\n \n U.S. Navy\n \n of 1861 was rapidly enlarged to 6,000 officers and 45,000 men in 1865, with 671 vessels, having a tonnage of 510,396.\n \n \n [128]\n \n \n \n \n [129]\n \n \n Its mission was to blockade Confederate ports, take control of the river system, defend against Confederate raiders on the high seas, and be ready for a possible war with the British\n \n Royal Navy\n \n .\n \n \n [130]\n \n \n Meanwhile, the main riverine war was fought in the West, where a series of major rivers gave access to the Confederate heartland. The U.S. Navy eventually gained control of the Red, Tennessee, Cumberland, Mississippi, and Ohio rivers. In the East, the Navy supplied and moved army forces about, and occasionally shelled Confederate installations.\n

\n

\n \n Modern navy evolves\n \n

\n
\n
\n \n \n \n
\n
\n \n \n
\n Clashes on the rivers were melees of\n \n ironclads\n \n ,\n \n cottonclads\n \n ,\n \n gunboats\n \n and rams, complicated by torpedoes and\n \n fire rafts\n \n .\n
\n
\n
\n

\n The Civil War occurred during the early stages of the industrial revolution. Many naval innovations emerged during this time, most notably the advent of the\n \n ironclad warship\n \n . It began when the Confederacy, knowing they had to meet or match the Union\'s naval superiority, responded to the Union blockade by building or converting more than 130 vessels, including twenty-six ironclads and floating batteries.\n \n \n [131]\n \n \n Only half of these saw active service. Many were equipped with ram bows, creating "ram fever" among Union squadrons wherever they threatened. But in the face of overwhelming Union superiority and the Union\'s ironclad warships, they were unsuccessful.\n \n \n [132]\n \n \n

\n
\n
\n \n \n \n
\n
\n \n \n
\n Battle between the Monitor and Merrimack.\n
\n
\n
\n

\n In addition to ocean-going warships coming up the Mississippi, the Union Navy used timberclads, tinclads, and armored gunboats. Shipyards at Cairo, Illinois, and St. Louis built new boats or modified steamboats for action.\n \n \n [133]\n \n \n

\n

\n The Confederacy experimented with the\n \n submarine\n \n \n CSS\n \n Hunley\n \n \n , which didn\'t work satisfactorily,\n \n \n [134]\n \n \n and with building an ironclad ship,\n \n CSS\n \n Virginia\n \n \n , which was based on rebuilding a sunken Union ship,\n \n \n Merrimack\n \n \n . On its first foray on March 8, 1862,\n \n Virginia\n \n inflicted significant damage to the Union\'s wooden fleet, but the next day the first Union ironclad,\n \n USS\n \n Monitor\n \n \n , arrived to challenge it in the\n \n Chesapeake Bay\n \n . The resulting three hour\n \n Battle of Hampton Roads\n \n was a draw, but it proved that ironclads were effective warships.\n \n \n [135]\n \n \n Not long after the battle the Confederacy was forced to scuttle the\n \n Virginia\n \n to prevent its capture, while the Union built many copies of the\n \n Monitor\n \n . Lacking the technology and infrastructure to build effective warships, the Confederacy attempted to obtain warships from Britain.\n \n \n [136]\n \n \n

\n

\n \n Union blockade\n \n

\n
\n Main article:\n \n Union blockade\n \n
\n
\n
\n \n \n \n
\n
\n \n \n
\n General Scott\'s "\n \n Anaconda Plan\n \n " 1861. Tightening naval blockade, forcing rebels out of Missouri along the Mississippi River, Kentucky Unionists sit on the fence, idled cotton industry illustrated in Georgia.\n
\n
\n
\n

\n By early 1861, General\n \n Winfield Scott\n \n had devised the\n \n Anaconda Plan\n \n to win the war with as little bloodshed as possible.\n \n \n [137]\n \n \n Scott argued that a Union blockade of the main ports would weaken the Confederate economy. Lincoln adopted parts of the plan, but he overruled Scott\'s caution about 90-day volunteers. Public opinion, however, demanded an immediate attack by the army to capture Richmond.\n \n \n [138]\n \n \n

\n

\n In April 1861, Lincoln announced the Union blockade of all Southern ports; commercial ships could not get insurance and regular traffic ended. The South blundered in embargoing cotton exports in 1861 before the blockade was effective; by the time they realized the mistake, it was too late. "King Cotton" was dead, as the South could export less than 10 percent of its cotton. The blockade shut down the ten Confederate seaports with railheads that moved almost all the cotton, especially New Orleans, Mobile, and Charleston. By June 1861, warships were stationed off the principal Southern ports, and a year later nearly 300 ships were in service.\n \n \n [139]\n \n \n

\n

\n \n Blockade runners\n \n

\n
\n Main article:\n \n Blockade runners of the American Civil War\n \n
\n
\n
\n \n \n \n
\n
\n \n \n
\n Gunline of nine Union ironclads.\n \n South Atlantic Blockading Squadron\n \n off Charleston. Continuous blockade of all major ports was sustained by North\'s ov erwhelming war production.\n
\n
\n
\n

\n British investors built small, fast, steam-driven\n \n blockade runners\n \n that traded arms and luxuries brought in from Britain through Bermuda, Cuba, and the Bahamas in return for high-priced cotton. Many of the ships were designed for speed and were so small that only a small amount of cotton went out.\n \n \n [140]\n \n \n When the Union Navy seized a blockade runner, the ship and cargo were condemned as a\n \n Prize of war\n \n and sold, with the proceeds given to the Navy sailors; the captured crewmen were mostly British, and they were released.\n \n \n [141]\n \n \n

\n

\n \n Economic impact\n \n

\n

\n The Southern economy nearly collapsed during the war. There were multiple reasons for this: the severe deterioration of food supplies, especially in cities, the failure of Southern railroads, the loss of control of the main rivers, foraging by Northern armies, and the seizure of animals and crops by Confederate armies.\n

\n

\n Most historians agree that the blockade was a major factor in ruining the Confederate economy; however, Wise argues that the blockade runners provided just enough of a lifeline to allow Lee to continue fighting for additional months, thanks to fresh supplies of 400,000 rifles, lead, blankets, and boots that the homefront economy could no longer supply.\n \n \n [142]\n \n \n

\n

\n Surdam argues that the blockade was a powerful weapon that eventually ruined the Southern economy, at the cost of few lives in combat. Practically, the entire Confederate cotton crop was useless (although it was sold to Union traders), costing the Confederacy its main source of income. Critical imports were scarce and the coastal trade was largely ended as well.\n \n \n [143]\n \n \n The measure of the blockade\'s success was not the few ships that slipped through, but the thousands that never tried it. Merchant ships owned in Europe could not get insurance and were too slow to evade the blockade, so they stopped calling at Confederate ports.\n \n \n [144]\n \n \n

\n

\n To fight an offensive war, the Confederacy purchased ships from Britain, converted them to warships, and raided American merchant ships in the Atlantic and Pacific oceans. Insurance rates skyrocketed and the American flag virtually disappeared from international waters. However, the same ships were reflagged with European flags and continued unmolested.\n \n \n [132]\n \n \n After the war, the U.S. demanded that Britain pay for the damage done, and Britain paid the U.S. $15 million in 1871.\n \n \n [145]\n \n \n

\n

\n \n Diplomacy\n \n

\n
\n Main article:\n \n Diplomacy of the American Civil War\n \n
\n

\n Although the Confederacy hoped that Britain and France would join them against the Union, this was never likely, and so they instead tried to bring Britain and France in as mediators.\n \n \n [146]\n \n \n \n \n [147]\n \n \n The Union, under Lincoln and Secretary of State\n \n William H. Seward\n \n worked to block this, and threatened war if any country officially recognized the existence of the Confederate States of America. In 1861, Southerners voluntarily embargoed cotton shipments, hoping to start an economic depression in Europe that would force Britain to enter the war to get cotton, but this did not work. Worse, Europe developed other cotton suppliers, which they found superior, hindering the South\'s recovery after the war.\n \n \n [148]\n \n \n

\n
\n
\n \n \n \n
\n
\n \n \n
\n Crewmembers of\n \n USS\n \n Wissahickon\n \n \n by the ship\'s 11-inch (280mm)\n \n Dahlgren gun\n \n , circa 1863\n
\n
\n
\n

\n \n Cotton diplomacy\n \n proved a failure as Europe had a surplus of cotton, while the 186062 crop failures in Europe made the North\'s grain exports of critical importance. It also helped to turn European opinion further away from the Confederacy. It was said that "King Corn was more powerful than King Cotton", as U.S. grain went from a quarter of the British import trade to almost half.\n \n \n [148]\n \n \n When Britain did face a cotton shortage, it was temporary, being replaced by increased cultivation in Egypt and India. Meanwhile, the war created employment for arms makers, ironworkers, and British ships to transport weapons.\n \n \n [149]\n \n \n

\n

\n Lincoln\'s administration failed to appeal to European public opinion. Diplomats explained that the United States was not committed to the ending of slavery, and instead repeated legalistic arguments about the unconstitutionality of secession. Confederate representatives, on the other hand, were much more successful by ignoring slavery and instead focusing on their struggle for liberty, their commitment to free trade, and the essential role of cotton in the European economy. The European aristocracy was "absolutely gleeful in pronouncing the American debacle as proof that the entire experiment in popular government had failed. European government leaders welcomed the fragmentation of the ascendant American Republic."\n \n \n [150]\n \n \n

\n

\n U.S.\n \n minister\n \n to Britain\n \n Charles Francis Adams\n \n proved particularly adept and convinced Britain not to boldly challenge the blockade. The Confederacy purchased several warships from commercial shipbuilders in Britain (\n \n CSS\n \n Alabama\n \n \n ,\n \n CSS\n \n Shenandoah\n \n \n ,\n \n CSS\n \n Tennessee\n \n \n ,\n \n CSS\n \n Tallahassee\n \n \n ,\n \n CSS\n \n Florida\n \n \n , and some others). The most famous, the\n \n CSS\n \n Alabama\n \n \n , did considerable damage and led to serious\n \n postwar disputes\n \n . However, public opinion against slavery created a political liability for politicians in Britain, where the antislavery movement was powerful.\n \n \n [151]\n \n \n

\n

\n War loomed in late 1861 between the U.S. and Britain over the\n \n \n Trent\n \n affair\n \n , involving the U.S. Navy\'s boarding of the British ship\n \n \n Trent\n \n \n and seizure of two Confederate diplomats. However, London and Washington were able to smooth over the problem after Lincoln released the two. In 1862, the British considered mediation between North and South, though even such an offer would have risked war with the United States. British Prime Minister\n \n Lord Palmerston\n \n reportedly read\n \n \n Uncle Tom\'s Cabin\n \n \n three times when deciding on this.\n \n \n [152]\n \n \n

\n

\n The Union victory in the\n \n Battle of Antietam\n \n caused them to delay this decision. The\n \n Emancipation Proclamation\n \n over time would reinforce the political liability of supporting the Confederacy. Despite sympathy for the Confederacy, France\'s\n \n seizure of Mexico\n \n ultimately deterred them from war with the Union. Confederate offers late in the war to end slavery in return for diplomatic recognition were not seriously considered by London or Paris. After 1863, the\n \n Polish revolt against Russia\n \n further distracted the European powers, and ensured that they would remain neutral.\n \n \n [153]\n \n \n

\n

\n \n Eastern theater\n \n

\n
\n
\n \n \n \n
\n
\n \n \n
\n \n County\n \n map of Civil War battles by theater and year\n
\n
\n
\n
\n Further information:\n \n Eastern Theater of the American Civil War\n \n
\n

\n The Eastern theater refers to the military operations east of the\n \n Appalachian Mountains\n \n , including the states of\n \n Virginia\n \n ,\n \n West Virginia\n \n ,\n \n Maryland\n \n , and\n \n Pennsylvania\n \n , the\n \n District of Columbia\n \n , and the coastal fortifications and seaports of\n \n North Carolina\n \n .\n

\n

\n \n Background\n \n

\n
\n
\n Army of the Potomac\n
\n
\n

\n Maj. Gen.\n \n George B. McClellan\n \n took command of the Union\n \n Army of the Potomac\n \n on July 26 (he was briefly general-in-chief of all the Union armies, but was subsequently relieved of that post in favor of Maj. Gen.\n \n Henry W. Halleck\n \n ), and the war began in earnest in 1862. The 1862 Union strategy called for simultaneous advances along four axes:\n \n \n [154]\n \n \n

\n
    \n
  1. \n McClellan would lead the main thrust in Virginia towards Richmond.\n
    2. \n
  2. \n Ohio forces would advance through Kentucky into Tennessee.\n
    3. \n
  3. \n The Missouri Department would drive south along the Mississippi River.\n
    4. \n
  4. \n The westernmost attack would originate from Kansas.\n
    5. \n
\n
\n
\n Army of Northern Virginia\n
\n
\n
\n
\n \n \n \n
\n
\n \n \n
\n Robert E. Lee\n
\n
\n
\n

\n The primary Confederate force in the Eastern theater was the\n \n Army of Northern Virginia\n \n . The Army originated as the\n \n (Confederate) Army of the Potomac\n \n , which was organized on June 20, 1861, from all operational forces in northern Virginia. On July 20 and July 21, the\n \n Army of the Shenandoah\n \n and forces from the District of Harpers Ferry were added. Units from the\n \n Army of the Northwest\n \n were merged into the Army of the Potomac between March 14 and May 17, 1862. The Army of the Potomac was renamed\n \n Army of Northern Virginia\n \n on March 14. The\n \n Army of the Peninsula\n \n was merged into it on April 12, 1862.\n

\n
\n
\n \n \n \n
\n
\n \n \n
\n Flag of Army of Northern Virginia\n
\n
\n
\n

\n When Virginia declared its secession in April 1861,\n \n Robert E. Lee\n \n chose to follow his home state, despite his desire for the country to remain intact and an offer of a senior Union command.\n

\n

\n Lee\'s biographer,\n \n Douglas S. Freeman\n \n , asserts that the army received its final name from Lee when he issued orders assuming command on June 1, 1862.\n \n \n [155]\n \n \n However, Freeman does admit that Lee corresponded with Brigadier General\n \n Joseph E. Johnston\n \n , his predecessor in army command, prior to that date and referred to Johnston\'s command as the Army of Northern Virginia. Part of the confusion results from the fact that Johnston commanded the Department of Northern Virginia (as of October 22, 1861) and the name Army of Northern Virginia can be seen as an informal consequence of its parent department\'s name. Jefferson Davis and Johnston did not adopt the name, but it is clear that the organization of units as of March 14 was the same organization that Lee received on June 1, and thus it is generally referred to today as the Army of Northern Virginia, even if that is correct only in retrospect.\n \n Jeb Stuart\n \n commanded the Army of Northern Virginia\'s cavalry.\n

\n

\n \n Battles\n \n

\n
\n
\n First Bull Run\n
\n
\n
\n
\n \n \n \n
\n
\n \n \n
\n "Stonewall" Jackson got his nickname at the First Battle of Bull Run.\n
\n
\n
\n

\n In one of the first highly visible battles, in July 1861, a march by Union troops under the command of\n \n Maj. Gen.\n \n \n Irvin McDowell\n \n on the Confederate forces led by Gen.\n \n P. G. T. Beauregard\n \n near Washington was repulsed at the\n \n First Battle of Bull Run\n \n .\n

\n
\n
\n \n \n \n
\n
\n \n \n
\n George McClellan\n
\n
\n
\n

\n The Union had the upper hand at first, nearly pushing confederate forces holding a defensive position into a rout, but Confederate reinforcements under. Joseph E. Johnston arrived from the\n \n Shenandoah Valley\n \n by railroad, and the course of the battle quickly changed. A\n \n brigade of Virginians\n \n under the relatively unknown brigadier general from the\n \n Virginia Military Institute\n \n ,\n \n Thomas J. Jackson\n \n , stood its ground, which resulted in Jackson receiving his famous nickname, "Stonewall".\n

\n
\n
\n McClellan\'s Peninsula Campaign; Jackson\'s Valley Campaign\n
\n
\n

\n Upon the strong urging of President Lincoln to begin offensive operations, McClellan attacked Virginia in the spring of 1862 by way of the\n \n peninsula\n \n between the\n \n York River\n \n and\n \n James River\n \n , southeast of Richmond. McClellan\'s army reached the gates of Richmond in the\n \n Peninsula Campaign\n \n ,\n \n \n [156]\n \n \n \n \n [157]\n \n \n \n \n [158]\n \n \n

\n
\n
\n \n \n \n
\n
\n \n \n
\n Union forces performing a bayonet charge, 1862\n
\n
\n
\n

\n Also in the spring of 1862, in the Shenandoah Valley, Stonewall Jackson led his\n \n Valley Campaign\n \n . Employing audacity and rapid, unpredictable movements on interior lines, Jackson\'s 17,000 men marched 646 miles (1,040km) in 48 days and won several minor battles as they successfully engaged three Union armies (52,000 men), including those of\n \n Nathaniel P. Banks\n \n and\n \n John C. Fremont\n \n , preventing them from reinforcing the Union offensive against Richmond. The swiftness of Jackson\'s men earned them the nickname of "foot-cavalry".\n

\n

\n Johnston halted McClellan\'s advance at the\n \n Battle of Seven Pines\n \n , but he was wounded in the battle, and Robert E. Lee assumed his position of command. General Lee and top subordinates\n \n James Longstreet\n \n and Stonewall Jackson defeated McClellan in the\n \n Seven Days Battles\n \n and forced his retreat.\n \n \n [159]\n \n \n

\n
\n
\n Second Bull Run\n
\n
\n

\n The\n \n Northern Virginia Campaign\n \n , which included the\n \n Second Battle of Bull Run\n \n , ended in yet another victory for the South.\n \n \n [160]\n \n \n McClellan resisted General-in-Chief Halleck\'s orders to send reinforcements to\n \n John Pope\'s\n \n Union\n \n Army of Virginia\n \n , which made it easier for Lee\'s Confederates to defeat twice the number of combined enemy troops.\n

\n
\n
\n Antietam\n
\n
\n
\n
\n \n \n \n
\n
\n \n \n
\n The\n \n Battle of Antietam\n \n , the Civil War\'s deadliest one-day fight.\n
\n
\n
\n

\n Emboldened by Second Bull Run, the Confederacy made its first invasion of the North with the\n \n Maryland Campaign\n \n . General Lee led 45,000 men of the Army of Northern Virginia across the\n \n Potomac River\n \n into Maryland on September 5. Lincoln then restored Pope\'s troops to McClellan. McClellan and Lee fought at the\n \n Battle of Antietam\n \n near\n \n Sharpsburg\n \n , Maryland, on September 17, 1862, the bloodiest single day in United States military history.\n \n \n [159]\n \n \n \n \n [161]\n \n \n Lee\'s army, checked at last, returned to Virginia before McClellan could destroy it. Antietam is considered a Union victory because it halted Lee\'s invasion of the North and provided an opportunity for Lincoln to announce his\n \n Emancipation Proclamation\n \n .\n \n \n [162]\n \n \n

\n
\n
\n First Fredericksburg\n
\n
\n

\n When the cautious McClellan failed to follow up on Antietam, he was replaced by Maj. Gen.\n \n Ambrose Burnside\n \n . Burnside was soon defeated at the\n \n Battle of Fredericksburg\n \n \n \n [163]\n \n \n on December 13, 1862, when more than 12,000 Union soldiers were killed or wounded during repeated futile frontal assaults against Marye\'s Heights. After the battle, Burnside was replaced by Maj. Gen.\n \n Joseph Hooker\n \n .\n

\n
\n
\n Chancellorsville\n
\n
\n
\n
\n \n \n \n
\n
\n \n \n
\n Confederate dead overrun at Marye\'s Heights, reoccupied next day May 4, 1863\n
\n
\n
\n

\n Hooker, too, proved unable to defeat Lee\'s army; despite outnumbering the Confederates by more than two to one, his Chancellorsville Campaign proved ineffective and he was humiliated in the\n \n Battle of Chancellorsville\n \n in May 1863.\n \n \n [164]\n \n \n Chancellorsville is known as Lee\'s "perfect battle" because his risky decision to divide his army in the presence of a much larger enemy force resulted in a significant Confederate victory. Gen. Stonewall Jackson was shot in the arm by accidental friendly fire during the battle and subsequently died of complications.\n \n \n [165]\n \n \n Lee famously said "He has lost his left arm; but I have lost my right arm."\n

\n

\n The fiercest fighting of the battleand the second bloodiest day of the Civil Waroccurred on May 3 as Lee launched multiple attacks against the Union position at Chancellorsville. That same day,\n \n John Sedgwick\n \n advanced across the\n \n Rappahannock River\n \n , defeated the small Confederate force at Marye\'s Heights in the\n \n Second Battle of Fredericksburg\n \n , and then moved to the west. The Confederates fought a successful delaying action at the\n \n Battle of Salem Church\n \n .\n

\n
\n
\n Gettysburg\n
\n
\n
\n
\n \n \n \n
\n
\n \n \n
\n Pickett\'s Charge\n
\n
\n
\n

\n Gen. Hooker was replaced by Maj. Gen.\n \n George Meade\n \n during Lee\'s\n \n second invasion of the North\n \n , in June. Meade defeated Lee at the\n \n Battle of Gettysburg\n \n (July 1 to 3, 1863).\n \n \n [166]\n \n \n This was the bloodiest battle of the war, and has been called the war\'s\n \n turning point\n \n .\n \n Pickett\'s Charge\n \n on July 3 is often considered the\n \n high-water mark of the Confederacy\n \n because it signaled the collapse of serious Confederate threats of victory. Lee\'s army suffered 28,000 casualties (versus Meade\'s 23,000).\n \n \n [167]\n \n \n However, Lincoln was angry that Meade failed to intercept Lee\'s retreat.\n

\n

\n \n Western theater\n \n

\n
\n Further information:\n \n Western Theater of the American Civil War\n \n
\n

\n The Western theater refers to military operations between the Appalachian Mountains and the\n \n Mississippi River\n \n , including the states of\n \n Alabama\n \n ,\n \n Georgia\n \n ,\n \n Florida\n \n ,\n \n Mississippi\n \n ,\n \n North Carolina\n \n ,\n \n Kentucky\n \n ,\n \n South Carolina\n \n and\n \n Tennessee\n \n , as well as parts of\n \n Louisiana\n \n .\n

\n

\n \n Background\n \n

\n
\n
\n Army of the Tennessee and Army of the Cumberland\n
\n
\n
\n
\n \n \n \n
\n
\n \n \n
\n Ulysses S. Grant\n
\n
\n
\n

\n The primary Union forces in the Western theater were the\n \n Army of the Tennessee\n \n and the\n \n Army of the Cumberland\n \n , named for the two rivers, the\n \n Tennessee River\n \n and\n \n Cumberland River\n \n . After Meade\'s inconclusive fall campaign, Lincoln turned to the Western Theater for new leadership. At the same time, the Confederate stronghold of Vicksburg surrendered, giving the Union control of the Mississippi River, permanently isolating the western Confederacy, and producing the new leader Lincoln needed,\n \n Ulysses S. Grant\n \n .\n

\n
\n
\n Army of Tennessee\n
\n
\n

\n The primary Confederate force in the Western theater was the\n \n Army of Tennessee\n \n . The army was formed on November 20, 1862, when General\n \n Braxton Bragg\n \n renamed the former\n \n Army of Mississippi\n \n . While the Confederate forces had numerous successes in the Eastern Theater, they were defeated many times in the West.\n

\n

\n \n Battles\n \n

\n
\n
\n Fort Henry and Fort Donelson\n
\n
\n

\n The Union\'s key strategist and tactician in the West was Ulysses S. Grant, who won victories at Forts\n \n Henry\n \n (February 6, 1862) and\n \n Donelson\n \n (February 11 to 16, 1862), by which the Union seized control of the Tennessee and Cumberland Rivers.\n \n Nathan Bedford Forrest\n \n rallied nearly 4,000 troops and led them to escape across the Cumberland.\n \n Nashville\n \n and central\n \n Tennessee\n \n thus fell to the Union, leading to attrition of local food supplies and livestock and a breakdown in social organization.\n

\n
\n
\n \n \n \n
\n
\n \n \n
\n Albert Sidney Johnston died at the Battle of Shiloh.\n
\n
\n
\n

\n \n Leonidas Polk\n \n \'s invasion of\n \n Columbus\n \n ended Kentucky\'s policy of neutrality and turned it against the Confederacy. Grant used river transport and\n \n Andrew Foote\'s\n \n gunboats of the Western Flotilla to threaten the Confederacy\'s "Gibraltar of the West" at Columbus, Kentucky. Although rebuffed at Belmont, Grant cut off Columbus. The Confederates, lacking their own gunboats, were forced to retreat and the Union took control of western Kentucky and opened Tennessee in March 1862.\n

\n
\n
\n Shiloh\n
\n
\n

\n At\n \n the Battle of Shiloh\n \n (Pittsburg Landing), in Tennessee in April 1862, the Confederates made a surprise attack that pushed Union forces against the river as night fell. Overnight, the Navy landed additional reinforcements, and Grant counter-attacked. Grant and the Union won a decisive victorythe first battle with the high casualty rates that would repeat over and over.\n \n \n [168]\n \n \n The Confederates lost\n \n Albert Sidney Johnston\n \n , considered their finest general before the emergence of Lee.\n

\n
\n
\n Union Navy captures Memphis\n
\n
\n

\n One of the early Union objectives in the war was the capture of the\n \n Mississippi River\n \n , in order to cut the Confederacy in half. "The key to the river was New Orleans, the South\'s largest port [and] greatest industrial center."\n \n \n [169]\n \n \n The Mississippi was opened to Union traffic to the southern border of Tennessee with the taking of\n \n Island No. 10\n \n and\n \n New Madrid\n \n , Missouri, and then\n \n Memphis, Tennessee\n \n .\n

\n
\n
\n \n \n \n
\n
\n \n \n
\n By 1863 the Union controlled large portions of the Western Theater, especially areas surrounding the Mississippi river\n
\n
\n
\n

\n In April 1862, the\n \n Union Navy\n \n \n captured New Orleans\n \n .\n \n \n [170]\n \n \n U.S. Naval forces under\n \n Farragut\n \n ran past Confederate defenses south of New Orleans. Confederate forces abandoned the city, giving the Union a critical anchor in the deep South.\n \n \n [171]\n \n \n which allowed Union forces to begin moving up the Mississippi.\n \n Memphis fell to Union forces\n \n on June 6, 1862, and became a key base for further advances south along the Mississippi River. Only the fortress city of\n \n Vicksburg\n \n , Mississippi, prevented Union control of the entire river.\n

\n
\n
\n Perryville\n
\n
\n

\n Bragg\'s second Confederate invasion of Kentucky included\n \n Kirby Smith\n \n \'s triumph at the\n \n Battle of Richmond\n \n and ended with a meaningless victory over Maj. Gen.\n \n Don Carlos Buell\n \n at the\n \n Battle of Perryville\n \n . Bragg was forced to end his attempt at invading Kentucky and retreat due to lack of support for the Confederacy in that state.\n \n \n [172]\n \n \n

\n
\n
\n Stones River\n
\n
\n

\n Bragg was narrowly defeated by Maj. Gen.\n \n William Rosecrans\n \n at the\n \n Battle of Stones River\n \n in\n \n Tennessee\n \n , the culmination of the\n \n Stones River Campaign\n \n .\n \n \n [173]\n \n \n

\n
\n
\n Vicksburg\n
\n
\n

\n Naval forces assisted Grant in the long, complex\n \n Vicksburg Campaign\n \n that resulted in the Confederates surrendering at the\n \n Battle of Vicksburg\n \n in July 1863, which cemented Union control of the Mississippi River and is considered one of the\n \n turning points\n \n of the war.\n \n \n [174]\n \n \n

\n
\n
\n Chickamauga\n
\n
\n
\n
\n \n \n \n
\n
\n \n \n
\n The\n \n Battle of Chickamauga\n \n , the highest two-day losses.\n
\n
\n
\n

\n The one clear Confederate victory in the West was the\n \n Battle of Chickamauga\n \n . After Rosecrans successful\n \n Tullahoma Campaign\n \n , Bragg, reinforced by Lt. Gen. James Longstreet\'s corps (from Lee\'s army in the east), defeated Rosecrans, despite the heroic defensive stand of Maj. Gen.\n \n George Henry Thomas\n \n .\n

\n
\n
\n Third Chattanooga\n
\n
\n

\n Rosecrans retreated to\n \n Chattanooga\n \n , which Bragg then besieged in the\n \n Chattanooga Campaign\n \n . Grant marched to the relief of Rosecrans and defeated Bragg at the\n \n Third Battle of Chattanooga\n \n ,\n \n \n [175]\n \n \n eventually causing Longstreet to abandon his\n \n Knoxville Campaign\n \n and driving Confederate forces out of Tennessee and opening a route to Atlanta and the heart of the Confederacy.\n

\n

\n \n Trans-Mississippi theater\n \n

\n
\n Further information:\n \n Trans-Mississippi Theater of the American Civil War\n \n
\n

\n \n Background\n \n

\n

\n The Trans-Mississippi theater refers to military operations west of the Mississippi River, not including the areas bordering the Pacific Ocean.\n

\n

\n \n Battles\n \n

\n
\n
\n Missouri\n
\n
\n
\n
\n \n \n \n
\n
\n \n \n
\n \n Nathaniel Lyon\n \n secured St. Louis docks and arsenal, led Union forces to expel Missouri Confederate forces and government.\n \n \n [176]\n \n \n
\n
\n
\n

\n The first battle of the Trans-Mississippi theater was the\n \n Battle of Wilson\'s Creek\n \n . The Confederates were driven from Missouri early in the war as a result of the\n \n Battle of Pea Ridge\n \n .\n \n \n [177]\n \n \n

\n

\n Extensive\n \n guerrilla warfare\n \n characterized the trans-Mississippi region, as the Confederacy lacked the troops and the logistics to support regular armies that could challenge Union control.\n \n \n [178]\n \n \n Roving Confederate bands such as\n \n Quantrill\'s Raiders\n \n terrorized the countryside, striking both military installations and civilian settlements.\n \n \n [179]\n \n \n The "Sons of Liberty" and "Order of the American Knights" attacked pro-Union people, elected officeholders, and unarmed uniformed soldiers. These partisans could not be entirely driven out of the state of Missouri until an entire regular Union infantry division was engaged. By 1864, these violent activities harmed the nationwide anti-war movement organizing against the re-election of Lincoln. Missouri not only stayed in the Union, but Lincoln took 70 percent of the vote for re-election.\n \n \n [180]\n \n \n

\n
\n
\n New Mexico\n
\n
\n

\n Numerous small-scale military actions south and west of Missouri sought to control\n \n Indian Territory\n \n and\n \n New Mexico Territory\n \n for the Union. The\n \n Battle of Glorieta Pass\n \n was the decisive\n \n battle\n \n of the\n \n New Mexico Campaign\n \n . The Union repulsed Confederate incursions into New Mexico in 1862, and the exiled Arizona government withdrew into Texas. In the Indian Territory, civil war broke out within tribes. About 12,000 Indian warriors fought for the Confederacy, and smaller numbers for the Union.\n \n \n [181]\n \n \n The most prominent Cherokee was Brigadier General\n \n Stand Watie\n \n , the last Confederate general to surrender.\n \n \n [182]\n \n \n

\n
\n
\n Texas\n
\n
\n

\n After the fall of\n \n Vicksburg\n \n in July 1863, General Kirby Smith in Texas was informed by Jefferson Davis that he could expect no further help from east of the Mississippi River. Although he lacked resources to beat Union armies, he built up a formidable arsenal at Tyler, along with his own Kirby Smithdom economy, a virtual "independent fiefdom" in Texas, including railroad construction and international smuggling. The Union in turn did not directly engage him.\n \n \n [183]\n \n \n Its 1864\n \n Red River Campaign\n \n to take Shreveport, Louisiana was a failure and Texas remained in Confederate hands throughout the war.\n

\n

\n \n Lower Seaboard theater\n \n

\n
\n Further information:\n \n Lower Seaboard Theater of the American Civil War\n \n
\n

\n \n Background\n \n

\n

\n The Lower Seaboard theater refers to military and naval operations that occurred near the coastal areas of the Southeast: in Alabama, Florida, Louisiana, Mississippi, South Carolina, and Texas) as well as southern part of the Mississippi River (Port Hudson and south). Union Naval activities were dictated by the Anaconda Plan.\n

\n

\n \n Battles\n \n

\n
\n
\n South Carolina\n
\n
\n

\n One of the earliest battles of the war was fought at\n \n Port Royal Sound\n \n , south of Charleston. Much of the war along the South Carolina coast concentrated on capturing\n \n Charleston\n \n . In attempting to capture Charleston, the Union military tried two approaches, by land over James or Morris Islands or through the harbor. However, the Confederates were able to drive back each Union attack. One of the most famous of the land attacks was the\n \n Second Battle of Fort Wagner\n \n , in which the\n \n 54th Massachusetts Infantry\n \n took part. The Federals suffered a serious defeat in this battle, losing 1,500 men while the Confederates lost only 175.\n

\n
\n
\n Georgia\n
\n
\n

\n Fort Pulaski on the Georgia coast was an early target for the Union navy. Following the capture of Port Royal, an expedition was organized with engineer troops under the command of Captain\n \n Quincy A. Gillmore\n \n , forcing a Confederate surrender. The Union army occupied the fort for the rest of the war after making repair.\n

\n
\n
\n Louisiana\n
\n
\n
\n
\n \n \n \n
\n
\n \n \n
\n New Orleans captured.\n
\n
\n
\n

\n In April 1862, a Union naval task force commanded by Commander\n \n David D. Porter\n \n attacked\n \n Forts Jackson and St. Philip\n \n , which guarded the river approach to New Orleans from the south. While part of the fleet bombarded the forts, other vessels forced a break in the obstructions in the river and enabled the rest of the fleet to steam upriver to the city. A Union army force commanded by Major General\n \n Benjamin Butler\n \n landed near the forts and forced their surrender. Butler\'s controversial command of New Orleans earned him the nickname "Beast".\n

\n

\n The following year, the Union\n \n Army of the Gulf\n \n commanded by Major General Nathaniel P. Banks laid\n \n siege to Port Hudson\n \n for nearly eight weeks, the longest siege in US military history. The Confederates attempted to defend with the\n \n Bayou Teche Campaign\n \n , but surrendered after Vicksburg. These two surrenders gave the Union control over the entire Mississippi.\n

\n
\n
\n Florida\n
\n
\n

\n Several small skirmishes were fought in Florida, but no major battles. The biggest was the\n \n Battle of Olustee\n \n in early 1864.\n

\n

\n \n Pacific Coast theater\n \n

\n
\n Further information:\n \n Pacific Coast Theater of the American Civil War\n \n
\n

\n The Pacific Coast theater refers to military operations on the Pacific Ocean and in the states and Territories west of the Continental Divide.\n

\n

\n \n Conquest of Virginia\n \n

\n

\n At the beginning of 1864, Lincoln made Grant commander of all Union armies. Grant made his headquarters with the Army of the Potomac, and put Maj. Gen.\n \n William Tecumseh Sherman\n \n in command of most of the western armies. Grant understood the concept of\n \n total war\n \n and believed, along with Lincoln and Sherman, that only the utter defeat of Confederate forces and their economic base would end the war.\n \n \n [184]\n \n \n This was total war not in killing civilians but rather in taking provisions and forage and destroying homes, farms, and railroads, that Grant said "would otherwise have gone to the support of secession and rebellion. This policy I believe exercised a material influence in hastening the end."\n \n \n [185]\n \n \n Grant devised a coordinated strategy that would strike at the entire Confederacy from multiple directions. Generals\n \n George Meade\n \n and Benjamin Butler were ordered to move against Lee near Richmond, General\n \n Franz Sigel\n \n (and later\n \n Philip Sheridan\n \n ) were to\n \n attack the Shenandoah Valley\n \n , General Sherman was to capture Atlanta and march to the sea (the Atlantic Ocean), Generals\n \n George Crook\n \n and\n \n William W. Averell\n \n were to operate against railroad supply lines in\n \n West Virginia\n \n , and Maj. Gen. Nathaniel P. Banks was to capture\n \n Mobile\n \n , Alabama.\n \n \n [186]\n \n \n

\n

\n \n \n \n Grant\'s Overland Campaign\n \n

\n
\n
\n \n \n \n
\n
\n \n \n
\n These dead soldiersfrom\n \n Ewell\n \n \'s May 1864 attack at\n \n Spotsylvania\n \n delayed Grant\'s advance on Richmond in the\n \n Overland Campaign\n \n .\n
\n
\n
\n
